Answer: No. Nobody has ever come close to what we have today, technologically. If ancient peoples had been making CAT scan machines or nuclear-powered aircraft carriers, we would know about it.It's possible that there have been societies that took care of their people better than we do, ensuring that everyone had a vote and access to justice and health care (such as it was). These things don't leave physical remains, but they still qualify as advancement.

Answer: Yes,They’reTechnology doesn’t progress in a linear fashion, nor do we expect it to. Technology begets technology. A wheel isn’t that impressive, technologically speaking, but when you’ve got a wheel you can transport loads farther and faster. It allowsYes,They’reTechnology doesn’t progress in a linear fashion, nor do we expect it to. Technology begets technology. A wheel isn’t that impressive, technologically speaking, but when you’ve got a wheel you can transport loads farther and faster. It allowsThe plow revolutionizes your farming techniques, which frees you to come up with evenMastering fire allows you to cook your food, which generally makes you healthier, which lets you live longer and you know…None of these things was invented in the last 150 years, I know, but I’m using them as illustrations of how one technological advancement paves the way for many, many more.And of course, as technology moves forward, there are new challenges to solve. That motivates people to create technology they weren’t even aware they would need in the past.The more technology youSo no, it isn’t suspicious at all that human technology languished in the “dark ages” for such a long time, and then reached a tipping point where it enabled people to live long, productive lives and dream up more technology. question: https://www.quora.com/What-was-the-peak-of-pre-human-technology

Answer: Because the dot com boom, as fun and exciting as it was to us participants, was more hype than reality.I joke that the entire industry consisted of five hundred founders, five hundred investors, and five hundred customers, all of whom were one or the other.Plus five or six magazines that pitched San Francisco, how fun and exciting it was, to a public that was dreaming of California. We’ve always been good at self-promotion through myth-making, whether it’s gold in the hills, or stardom, skate boarding, wine, or living rich and beautiful. So it was with the Net.We were building some great pipesBecause the dot com boom, as fun and exciting as it was to us participants, was more hype than reality.I joke that the entire industry consisted of five hundred founders, five hundred investors, and five hundred customers, all of whom were one or the other.Plus five or six magazines that pitched San Francisco, how fun and exciting it was, to a public that was dreaming of California. We’ve always been good at self-promotion through myth-making, whether it’s gold in the hills, or stardom, skate boarding, wine, or living rich and beautiful. So it was with the Net.We were building some great pipes to carry information, money, goods and services, infrastructure for the online world. But they were small pipes, mock-ups and experiments really, and they didn’t carry any money.Some of the more visionary people like Steve Jobs, Jeff Bezos, the people who started Paypal, Craig Newmark (of Craigslist), Sergey and Larry at google, the boosters at Wired Magazine, the forerunners of Facebook, the Burning Man crowd, saw that the new technology would make a huge difference to life, money, and culture. We all could, I think. It was inevitable. If you take a sentient species of life and give them the ability to read, type, compute and transmit data, somebody is going to invent the internet.What’s happening today is just that it has come to fruition because everybody now has fast internet access and laws that protect providers against the misdeeds of users. There is a critical mass of support services: geolocation, payments, cloud hosting, micropayments, analytics, development tools. But mostly, it’s because everybody is online and not afraid to use it. So the cool things we did 20–25 years ago for our five hundred friends and five million dollars are now being done for five hundredAs a side note, technology has always been a huge part of the stock market – power companies, railroads, computers, factories, telegraph companies, airplane manufacturers, cash registers, defense contractors, medicine and biotech. It’s all technology, just not online technology.

It is actually all technologies that center around digital technology, robot technology, artificial intelligence, Distributed Ledger Technology, Digital currencies, autonomous vehicles, communications, new advances to the internet and searches beyond Google, social medias, and much more.This surge of new technology touches all of the 140+ industries in the US and around the world. The dot coms were the beginning of online shopping. But this new technology is far more extensive and impacts major industries in waysWe are in the early stages of what is being called the 4th Industrial Revolution. It is actually all technologies that center around digital technology, robot technology, artificial intelligence, Distributed Ledger Technology, Digital currencies, autonomous vehicles, communications, new advances to the internet and searches beyond Google, social medias, and much more.This surge of new technology touches all of the 140+ industries in the US and around the world. The dot coms were the beginning of online shopping. But this new technology is far more extensive and impacts major industries in ways that is totally disruptive and displacement.What is coming is staggering in breadth and depth and will change society, governments, manufacturing, jobs, education, healthcare, travel, entertainment, leisure, marketing in ways that is incomprehensible for most people.Imagine someone from 1950 seeing all of what we have now as our normal every day technologies: smart phones and access to everything via the phone. How we communicate, work, and play. Now multiply what we have compared to 1950 by a factor of 10. That is the scope of the changes that are coming in the next 20 years.

question: https://www.quora.com/Why-is-the-influence-of-technology-companies-on-the-US-stock-market-even-greater-now-than-it-was-during-the-peak-of-the-dot-com-era

Answer: Because so little of the economy was using technology at the turn of the century. Millenia. We used computers but on a very limited basis. Data recording, number crunching, and mail. No training, no video calls, no meetings. Most of the companies didn’t exist and those that did were quite different. Amazon was a text book then regular book seller. Kindle didn't exist. Now if you can’t find it on Amazon it nearly doesn’t exist. Back then it was potential they were buying. 20 years later this stuff is real, functional and even a necessity for businesses and consumers.

Answer: Due to the pandemic, earnings for the great majority of companies will be significantly less than previous years.Conversely, many tech companies are having a booming year, because of the pandemic. As a result, many investors have bid up the prices of these winners.Most institutional investors have set rules, regarding the reallocation of assets. As a result, when their holdings in one company, ETF, or index reaches their limit, the institution automatically sells some shares and buys more shares of an underperforming stock, ETF, or index.Plus, numerous hedge funds short the winners, when priceDue to the pandemic, earnings for the great majority of companies will be significantly less than previous years.Conversely, many tech companies are having a booming year, because of the pandemic. As a result, many investors have bid up the prices of these winners.Most institutional investors have set rules, regarding the reallocation of assets. As a result, when their holdings in one company, ETF, or index reaches their limit, the institution automatically sells some shares and buys more shares of an underperforming stock, ETF, or index.Plus, numerous hedge funds short the winners, when prices are at historic highs.Throw in a very contentious election and you get increased volatility.

Answer: This is the horse and buggy question. And it's a good one to think about.I think fax machines and printers have peaked and begun to decline.Now I know what you're thinking…Fax machines? Printers?Who uses these devices?Me. Not fax machines but I still use a printer. Sometimes it's easier to see a physical piece of paper then to stare at the screen all the time.But fax machines? There's no excuse here. Xerox lost its technology leadership since the industry has been declining for years. Email and the internet have killed it. But someone still sends faxes...In fact, fax machines aren't even securThis is the horse and buggy question. And it's a good one to think about.I think fax machines and printers have peaked and begun to decline.Now I know what you're thinking…Fax machines? Printers?Who uses these devices?Me. Not fax machines but I still use a printer. Sometimes it's easier to see a physical piece of paper then to stare at the screen all the time.But fax machines? There's no excuse here. Xerox lost its technology leadership since the industry has been declining for years. Email and the internet have killed it. But someone still sends faxes...In fact, fax machines aren't even secure or safe for data transfers. But older people still use them. Or they have them around the house or office.So the decline of fax machines are easier to predict.But I think printers are more likely to be replaced next.The next generation of techies are completely online.They're not saving printer paper because they are eco-friendly. They're not printing because they don't need paper. And I like this future.There's no reason to create better printers as we've moved on from the horse and buggy.

Answer: It’s a lot more than you think.A modern US infantry brigade with enough supplies could take on the combined militaries of the ancient world with no trouble at all.But modern soldiers in the ancient world would have two problems.First is that whole “enough supplies” thing. A US combat brigade requires an enormous amount of logistics and support to keep it operational. The US army has always been famous for chewing through supplies at a prodigious rate but being able to replace them as much as needed. There would be no supply train or fuel/ammo dumps in ancient Mesopotamia the same way there areIt’s a lot more than you think.A modern US infantry brigade with enough supplies could take on the combined militaries of the ancient world with no trouble at all.But modern soldiers in the ancient world would have two problems.First is that whole “enough supplies” thing. A US combat brigade requires an enormous amount of logistics and support to keep it operational. The US army has always been famous for chewing through supplies at a prodigious rate but being able to replace them as much as needed. There would be no supply train or fuel/ammo dumps in ancient Mesopotamia the same way there are now. A modern soldier with no fuel, ammo, or transport is essentially a guy with a fancy club.The second is the whole “take over the world” thing. Let’s say the modern soldiers magically have all the supplies they need. They swoop into Mediolanum, crush all resistance there, raise the American flag, and move on to their next target. What happens when they are gone? The Romans left behind an administrative structure and a garrison in newly conquered lands. Territories weren’t left without a military presence until they had ben safely Roman for a while. Even then there were revolts. Our invincible modern army is going to spend all of its time conquering places, none of which they can hold. And the world is a really big place. Rome was at its peak in AD 100, at which time there were flourishing cultures in China, India, Japan, Africa, the Americas, and so on. All of these places need to be conquered, subdued, and then held. Who is going to do it? Remember that a good chunk of the US military was in Afghanistan for years and the place was hardly pacified. If a people don’t want to stay conquered, and you aren’t there anymore, it is very hard to keep them that way.
name: Pieter
question: https://www.quora.com/What-was-the-peak-of-pre-human-technology

Answer: Weirdly, Valves.Boring, simple valves. They let water out. They keep water in. So what?But the Romans, lacking machine tools and industrialized manufacturing, produced surprisingly standardized and precise in line valves to finely control the water supply to public baths, fountains and quite often, individual homes.The design was simple, a bronze or bronze alloy junction piece with a tightly fitting plug cylinder sleeved within it. This had holes in. Turn the spindle at the top and the holes align with the pipe allowing water to pass through and vice versa.Some modern valves you get from the hWeirdly, Valves.Boring, simple valves. They let water out. They keep water in. So what?But the Romans, lacking machine tools and industrialized manufacturing, produced surprisingly standardized and precise in line valves to finely control the water supply to public baths, fountains and quite often, individual homes.The design was simple, a bronze or bronze alloy junction piece with a tightly fitting plug cylinder sleeved within it. This had holes in. Turn the spindle at the top and the holes align with the pipe allowing water to pass through and vice versa.Some modern valves you get from the hardware shop work the same way and look surprisingly similar.Simple, but to make it work it must be robust and precisely measured. The plug insert has to be a precise fit or it will leak or Caesar up. Ahem sorry,You see, a valve isn't just a valve.If you work back through the reverse butterfly effect of what is required to make a simple device standard across a whole empire that everyone uses, you see it takes a huge amount of collective effort.We have the benefit of fine machine tools, synthetic polymers, stainless steel, a literate population that can read and count, standardized factories. Decades of craftsmen and engineers talking with each other, comparing designs, sharing best practice.You need people to travel to demonstrate to craftsmen what is required. To travel you need efficient transport, or at least roads, and therefor a robust government administration to put that in place.You have to have literacy and numeracy to a degree, otherwise you will have simply a hundred differing artistic interpretations of “valve”, not an empirical design.You need enough of the workforce producing enough of a food surplus that a segment of the population can specialize in making stuff that isn't food. Like valves.All this has to be in place first.Rome, at its heart, was a slave owning economy based on simple agriculture. Human and animal muscle power drove it, and the wind helped blow its ships. In that respect it was little different from the Minoans, Egyptians, Assyrians or any other nameless, ancient culture.And yet the pre-industrial Romans managed to coordinate themselves to such a degree that small groups of craftsmen, as far apart as northern England and Egypt, with hand tools in simple workshops, could produce a standard device that could, literally, plug into a standard plumbing system in different corners of the empire.We picture the great aqueducts sweeping into the cities dumping water into troughs while the eager plebs gather around with their buckets.In actual fact it was a lot more elegant, and indeed modern, than that.
